text: Modelling question: I have a model, A, that by standard statistical tests performs better than model B (higher ROC, better precision/recall etc). However, on backtest, model B results in higher Sharpe and more total pnl. How would one choose which model to use? My theory is that model A is just better at forecasting situations that are already easy for the market to forecast too, and therefore unlikely to find opportunities where the market gets this wrong (hence an opportunity to take a position in the market). Note: Model B is just fit on a subset of features.

elements.text: Modelling question: I have a model, A, that by standard statistical tests performs better than model B (higher ROC, better precision/recall etc). However, on backtest, model B results in higher Sharpe and more total pnl. How would one choose which model to use? My theory is that model A is just better at forecasting situations that are already easy for the market to forecast too, and therefore unlikely to find opportunities where the market gets this wrong (hence an opportunity to take a position in the market). Note: Model B is just fit on a subset of features.

text: Good q - no. Mainly because I like to keep my out-of-sample data to be always ahead of my training data in terms of when the events occurred. But maybe this is not reasonable. I thought perhaps it might not be sensible to have a split where training is April to Sept and validation is Jan to March you know. But this also means I can't do cross validation which is annoying.

text: yes great to obviously do you test train split prior, maybe  cross validation also in theory should be done on a separate split. Id recommend running a few goes, sometimes you get a good split that maybe be very good in some years and awful in others (worth trying a few variations of the stratify field). Data leakage and data duplicates are always the killer. If results look to good your mostly likely got one of those issues (check BSP isnt included, or any data after the fact).

text: You guys who do proper modelling based on variables / fundamentals as opposed to pure market / price based backfitting , how do you go about your sport(s) when subject to a new rule change or similar? Or something like covid era where home advantage effect is very likely altered by absence of crowds. Mainly I am thinking about introduction of VAR in football which was a big one, but in other sports there are subtle rule changes introduced at times. Do you just run prior models on the "new" version of the sport and carefully monitor for differences in your expected profits or do you shut up shop until you can rebuild a model from "new" data as it becomes available?

elements.text: You guys who do proper modelling based on variables / fundamentals as opposed to pure market / price based backfitting , how do you go about your sport(s) when subject to a new rule change or similar? Or something like covid era where home advantage effect is very likely altered by absence of crowds. Mainly I am thinking about introduction of VAR in football which was a big one, but in other sports there are subtle rule changes introduced at times. Do you just run prior models on the "new" version of the sport and carefully monitor for differences in your expected profits or do you shut up shop until you can rebuild a model from "new" data as it becomes available?

text: Sharpe ratio penalises excess positive returns to the same extent as negative. Alternatives without this shortcoming include the Omega ratio which I like because of its ease of construction - it’s just the sum of the positive returns divided by the sum of the absolute of the negative returns. Jack Schwager in his Market Wizards series of books espouses the adjusted Sortino ratio although I’m not familiar with it myself

elements.text: Sharpe ratio penalises excess positive returns to the same extent as negative. Alternatives without this shortcoming include the Omega ratio which I like because of its ease of construction - it’s just the sum of the positive returns divided by the sum of the absolute of the negative returns. Jack Schwager in his Market Wizards series of books espouses the adjusted Sortino ratio although I’m not familiar with it myself

text: the difference in sports compared to finance is the payoffs are not usually symmetric unless you're wagering close to 2.0. Further your loses are capped. In finance, generally, you don't have a loss cap, and distributions are more symmetric (I'll ignore option payoffs here as this topic gets very deep). In general in finance, if you see a move upwards, you would expect a similar size move downwards possible (again, lets ignore options payoffs for the moment otherwise I would need to type for days). As a consequence I usually like the sharpe ratio in that domain as it's conservative. You could be unlucky one day and be on the wrong side on that certain day (particularly if you're making a lot of trades). That said, I agree with Mo that sharpe is not super useful to use in sports betting.

elements.text: the difference in sports compared to finance is the payoffs are not usually symmetric unless you're wagering close to 2.0. Further your loses are capped. In finance, generally, you don't have a loss cap, and distributions are more symmetric (I'll ignore option payoffs here as this topic gets very deep). In general in finance, if you see a move upwards, you would expect a similar size move downwards possible (again, lets ignore options payoffs for the moment otherwise I would need to type for days). As a consequence I usually like the sharpe ratio in that domain as it's conservative. You could be unlucky one day and be on the wrong side on that certain day (particularly if you're making a lot of trades). That said, I agree with Mo that sharpe is not super useful to use in sports betting.

text: I'm far from being a stats expert so maybe this is bollocks - but doesn't it depend on your sample size? Surely the various statistical tests essentially just substitute for a larger sample, so if you have a big sample you just go for the biggest profit and if your sample is limited you lean towards the models that perform best on the statistical tests... or is that wrong?

elements.text: I'm far from being a stats expert so maybe this is bollocks - but doesn't it depend on your sample size? text: <@US2K70JR0> I guess that raises the q of what is "big sample". In my case I thought my holdout set on which these metrics are computed is big enough, and so I was just surprised a model that shows up as having better predictive ability was yielding worse results backtest-wise (I.e. when you bring the forecasts to the market). Probably just the case that the dataset is not large enough and just seeing some continued variance. Might as well run both models on 50% of events each and see how it goes.

text: That's a good question, I was just about to comment about it! The more complex model requires a larger history to exist for each team, and naturally it cuts the tradeable number of events down by about 20%. It's possible that the uncertainty in this 20% is larger, therefore more market innefficiency and higher margins opportunities that the simpler model is able to take advantage of. I'll check the margin on these 20% and see if it massively outweighs the rest

text: Personally I'm not keen on <@U4H19D1D2>'s approach to this problem for a few reasons, one of which is that you can easily end up with a proliferation of poorly optimised models that might be interacting in all kinds of ways that you'll never know about. I prefer to try to understand the features I'm using as deeply as possible and integrate them into a single unified model wherever possible.

text: <@U4H19D1D2> In this case maybe but you're still just kicking the can down the road. What are you going to do when you find another feature? Start a model C and run that too? Just in the general case I don't like to approach. You can make it better by having some structure like a perpetual AvB with a 'winner stays on' structure or something like that but you can see the potential for muddying the waters if you don't. I suppose it is a question of style and how you manage your development though.

elements.text: In this case maybe but you're still just kicking the can down the road. What are you going to do when you find another feature? Start a model C and run that too? I suppose it is a question of style and how you manage your development though.

text: <@UQL0QDEKA> Like I said to an extent it's a question of style, but if you're running a lot of variations on a theme it would presumably be quite easy to identify the commonalities in them and bring them all into a single strategy with triggers that cover all reasonable variations. Wouldn't that be better? If there is sufficient capacity for overlap why not just explicitly place more or bigger bets at those times?

text: What Ive found is that if you run a single profitable strategy and the stakes scale, you eventually hit a point where you cant increase stakes - diminishing returns, (im talking in play horses now, not football where the volume is much greater). Id rather have 10 systems using smaller stakes than a single one using large stakes. Its just my preference <@UGV299K6H>.

text: I think a lot of this comes down to how you do your analysis. Some people are into analysing the performance of a strategy as a whole and will test strategy A against strategy B and so on. To me this doesn't make much sense as your strategy is only visible or meaningful to you, the exchange only sees your bets and treats them individually. Personally I like to take my bets independently of whatever triggered them and analyse them that way round.

elements.text: I think a lot of this comes down to how you do your analysis. Some people are into analysing the performance of a strategy as a whole and will test strategy A against strategy B and so on. To me this doesn't make much sense as your strategy is only visible or meaningful to you, the exchange only sees your bets and treats them individually. Personally I like to take my bets independently of whatever triggered them and analyse them that way round.

text: That way you get to see and understand the variables that determine the value of each bet and you can feed that knowledge back into your strategy.

elements.text: That way you get to see and understand the variables that determine the value of each bet and you can feed that knowledge back into your strategy.

text: Yes Id agree with the piece about understanding what triggered them initially, but the second part of that (and this is what I mean about a ‘variation of a theme’) is how your bot responds to those triggers. You can have just one trigger but two bots responding just slightly different.

elements.text: Yes Id agree with the piece about understanding what triggered them initially, but the second part of that (and this is what I mean about a ‘variation of a theme’) is how your bot responds to those triggers. You can have just one trigger but two bots responding just slightly different.
